Award.AwardTitle: Type-1 Photochemical Reaction Centers: Paradigm, Variations, and Applications

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit

This project presents an integrated, comprehensive research and training program that focuses broadly on the topics of environment and energy - through its focus on important fundamental and applied aspects of research on natural photosynthesis. The research will be conducted jointly in the laboratories of Co-PIs Donald A. Bryant and John H. Golbeck, who have collaborated on research in natural photosynthesis for more than twenty years. The central "paradigm" of this project derives from research to understand the structural and functional details of type-1 photochemical reaction center (RCs) of Cyanobacteria. The potential impact of the work in terms of significance to the environment includes the biochemical characterization a newly discovered, oxygen-tolerant homodimeric Type-1 RC (Aim 1); determining the functional, environmental, and potentially evolutionary relevance of multiple copies of genes encoding Photosystem I (PS I) subunits in an iron-loving cyanobacterium, (Aim 2); conducting studies of cyanobacterial thylakoid membrane and PS I biogenesis using conditionally controlled gene expression in the model cyanobacterium Synechococcus sp. PCC 7002 (Aim 3). The potential impact of the project in terms of significance to solar energy involves characterizing the dynamics of primary charge separation in PS I (Aim 4). The application of knowledge gained from the studies proposed herein, as well as those conducted during more than 20 years of NSF-supported research by the Co-PIs, is evident in the proposed development of a PS I-molecular wire construct to serve as a light-driven, electron-injection device to study the mechanisms of proton-coupled, electron transfer reactions in redox-active enzymes (Aim 5). The successful completion of this research program will significantly increase an understanding of the mechanism of primary charge separation in type-1 RCs and should also provide instructive new insights for the future development of devices to perform solar energy capture and conversion. There are excellent reasons to believe that it may be possible to identify an inorganic catalyst that is synthesized biologically and that would mimic the Fischer-Tropsch reaction but generate C-C bonds at 298 K and 1 bar.

Broader Impacts

This research program is designed to present outstanding training opportunities that will allow the Co-PIs to co-mentor graduate and undergraduate students in topics that include microbial ecology, physiology, genetics, genomics, biochemistry, and biophysics. One reason for merging these research programs into a single program was to provide broader, better integrated training to students, whom will thus be able to think more globally about issues concerning energy and the environment. The aims of this proposal were similarly organized in such a way to illustrate how these projects progress logically from studies with their origins in microbial ecology and the environment to those that are firmly based in biochemistry and biophysics. Based upon their combined, broad research interests and perspectives in natural photosynthesis, light harvesting, and solar energy conversion processes, the Co-PIs will help to train the next generation of academic and industrial scientists in a field that is growing in importance to the strategic interests and long-term economic prosperity of our society. The Co-PIs will continue their extensive involvement in outreach and synergistic relationships in science. Important aspects of this effort include a commitment to involving both faculty and students at exclusively or predominantly undergraduate institutions in our research program. The Co-PIs are committed to continuing their current training of students who are members of underrepresented minorities in science. Finally, outreach and educational activities at the high school and grade school levels are planned.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was an comprehensive research and training program that broadly focused on the topics of solar energy capture, conversion, and the environment. The central “paradigm” for the proposal was based on nearly three decades of studies on the Photosystem I (PSI) reaction center (RC), one of the two protein machines that directly converts energy from sunlight into biochemical potential energy in photosynthetic organisms (e.g., plants, algae, cyanobacteria,). The project had five broad aims: (1) characterization of the novel, oxygen-tolerant, homodimeric Type-1 RCs of Chloracidobacterium thermophilum [These RCs are simpler and evolutionarily ancestral to the more complex PSI RCs in cyanobacteria and plants.]; (2) characterize the PSI RCs from an iron-loving cyanobacterium from Yellowstone National Park; (3) determine the role of the VIPP1 protein in thylakoid membrane biogenesis; (4) further characterize the dynamics of charge separation in PSI; (5) use knowledge of PSI to create light-driven, electron injection devices for redox-active enzymes. Additionally, this NSF project provided support for long-term studies on the physiology, metabolism, and gene regulation in the model cyanobacterium, Synechococcus sp. PCC 7002.

 Substantial progress was made towards all goals. Most notably, studies on aim (2) led to the discovery of a previously unknown acclimation response in some terrestrial cyanobacteria that allows these organisms to perform photosynthesis using light in the wavelength range 700 to 800 nm (far-red light). This process, which was named far-red light photoacclimation (FaRLiP), results in extraordinary remodeling of the photosynthetic machinery in such organisms. The genes/proteins that control this process were identified, and the enzyme responsible for the synthesis of the key pigment, chlorophyll f (Chl f) was identified. Chl f is the reason that FaRLiP-capable cyanobacteria can grow and perform photosynthesis in far-red light. A surprising discovery was that this enzyme, ChlF, is light-dependent and is distantly related to a core subunit of the Photosystem II (PSII) RC, which produces the oxygen that is crucial to life on Earth. Our results suggested that the evolutionary pressure to expand light harvesting into the far-red region of the solar spectrum may have been the selection pressure to initiate the evolutionary process that eventually led to the capacity of PSII to oxidize water. The identification of the enzyme for Chl f synthesis has implications for expanding the wavelength range for photosynthesis by introducing the ability to synthesize Chl f into crop plants. This is an important goal of plant genetic engineering.

 Another important outcome of this project was the discovery that the tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle of most cyanobacteria is not branched, as previously believed, but is in fact a complete, cyclic pathway. We identified the two genes/enzymes responsible for closing the cycle and demonstrated their biochemical activities. This work identified a novel metabolite, succinic semialdehyde, which is useful for metabolic engineering to produce certain high-value or biofuel-related products in cyanobacteria. We additionally characterized two other variants of the TCA cycle, the glyoxylate and gamma-aminobutyric acid shunts. These studies corrected misconceptions about the TCA cycle in cyanobacteria that had persisted for nearly five decades. 

Another misconception corrected by these studies concerned the function of the VIPP1 protein. It was generally believed that VIPP1 was essential for viability in cyanobacteria and plants, and that it was essential because it was required for the synthesis of photosynthetic membranes (i.e., thylakoids) in plant chloroplasts and cyanobacteria. We showed that VIPP1 is not essential for cyanobacterial viability. Instead, VIPP1 is essential for the biogenesis of PSI but does not seem to affect thylakoid membrane biogenesis directly.

The first detailed studies were performed on the Type-1 RCs of Chloracidobacterium thermophilum, a bacterium recently discovered and isolated from hot spring mats in Yellowstone National Park. The RCs were shown to contain three types of Chls: Chl a, bacteriochlorophyll a, and Zn-bacteriochlorophyll a’. More recent studies have shown that two molecules of Zn-bacteriochlorophyll a’ form the primary donor in these RCs, their core where initial photochemical charge separation occurs in response to light.

Finally, progress was made towards understanding electron transfer processes that occur in PSI RCs of Synechococcus sp. PCC 7002. A thermodynamic and kinetic model of these processes was proposed and validated. These studies showed that the terminal electron transfer cofactors of PSI reaction centers, i.e., two phylloquinone molecules and three [4Fe4S] clusters, can be operated as a passive switch to control the fate of electrons that reach the phylloquinones. By removing or by reducing the Fe/S clusters, electrons can be captured by chemically modified, introduced, phylloquinone derivatives; these captured electrons can be shunted away from the RCs to catalysts to perform interesting, light-driven reduction reactions. Hydrogen can be produced in this manner by coupling the phylloquinone-like molecule to a Pt-nanoparticle catalyst. These studies have important implications for understanding multi-electron reduction processes in biology because the process can be controlled by ultra-short flashes of light from lasers.
